title.narrative: OUTPUT 2 [SOCIAL PROTECTION]

description.narrative: By the end of 2019, coordination bodies of social protection programmes at national and subnational levels have the skills and resources to take care of the poorest children and those living with disability, through various safety social nets (health, education, nutrition), which contributes to Environmental Sustainability, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Social Protection, Social Protection And Child Poverty. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: [Social Policy and Inclusion]: By 2019, national and sub-national social policies are more inclusive and equitable, promoting the resilience of families and vulnerable communities.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By the end of 2019, coordination bodies of social protection programmes at national and subnational levels have the skills andresources to take care of the poorest children and those living with disability, through various safety social nets (health,education, nutrition)

description.narrative: UNICEF strengthened capacities of the Government to deliver social protection to vulnerable families and expand access to free health care to poorest children. The Unified Social Register, officially launched in November 2019, will allow beneficiaries of cash transfers to be linked with other programme information systems. The population covered by a health insurance plan increased from 6.35% in 2018 to 10.4% in 2019. An estimated 18.4 million persons (78% of the total population) is currently not covered by any social protection mechanisms. During 2019, with UNICEF support, 39,323 children benefited from free health care under the RAMED programme. | Status:Partially met | As-of Date:07/02/2020
